text: A process is a program in execution. Each process has its own address space and executes concurrently with others. Concurrency occurs when multiple processes are in progress at the same time, requiring the operating system to manage resources and coordinate their interactions. Operating systems provide mechanisms such as process scheduling, inter‑process communication and threads to enable concurrency. Threads are lightweight processes that share the same address space but can run independently. Concurrency can increase system throughput and resource utilisation, but it introduces challenges like synchronization, data races and deadlock, which must be handled by careful design of software and operating systems【614508547114889†L30-L56】.

Modern distributed systems are built from multiple computers working together as a single logical system. This course introduces the fundamentals of distributed systems by examining their performance, resilience and scalability. Students learn to describe the principles of distributed computing, contrast distributed systems with other forms of computation, identify real‑world applications such as cloud services, big data processing and interactive gaming, analyse and design distributed architectures, and solve practical problems. The course emphasises non‑functional requirements—performance, reliability and scalability—and encourages learners to think critically about how to design robust distributed software【564203167852649†L83-L135】. The materials are licensed under Creative Commons Attribution‑NonCommercial‑ShareAlike 4.0【564203167852649†L149-L153】.

The MIT course "Distributed Computer Systems Engineering" presents abstractions and implementation techniques for building reliable distributed systems. It covers server design and concurrency, network programming, naming and directory services, caching and replication, storage systems and security. Special attention is given to fault tolerance: students study how replicating data and services can improve availability and learn to design systems that continue to operate correctly despite component failures. Assignments include building small distributed services and evaluating their performance. MIT OpenCourseWare materials are released under a Creative Commons Attribution‑NonCommercial‑ShareAlike licence【41876357063460†L51-L78】.

In Computer System Engineering, a lecture on fault tolerance shows how distributed systems can remain available in the presence of failures. Reliability is quantified using metrics such as mean time to failure (MTTF), mean time to repair (MTTR) and availability, which is the proportion of time a system is operational. The lecture discusses replication strategies, including primary–backup replication and state machine replication, and demonstrates how to use redundant arrays of independent disks (RAID) to cope with disk failures. Students learn to evaluate trade‑offs between reliability, performance and cost, and to design systems that continue to function correctly despite hardware or software faults【818261708173847†L470-L553】. All MIT OpenCourseWare materials are provided under a Creative Commons Attribution‑NonCommercial‑ShareAlike licence【41876357063460†L51-L78】.

A lecture on distributed systems in the performance engineering course compares building a single large multiprocessor with assembling a cluster of commodity machines. The lecturer explains that clusters are often cheaper, easier to scale and more reliable: when one node fails, others continue to operate. Clusters can be expanded incrementally by adding servers and network switches, enabling organisations to grow computing capacity as needed. This approach has enabled data centres and cloud providers to offer scalable services at low cost. The transcript is published under a Creative Commons licence【311372312008449†L35-L146】【311372312008449†L0-L8】.

This lecture on system integration introduces service‑oriented architecture (SOA). It explains that SOA uses web services built on open standards—XML for data representation, SOAP for messaging and WSDL for service description—and publishes services in a registry so they can be discovered and reused. Services can be composed to build complex workflows, enabling the integration of heterogeneous systems with loose coupling and asynchronous communication. The lecture contrasts SOA with earlier enterprise integration approaches and highlights features such as platform independence, dynamic discovery and orchestration of services【889065031174357†L50-L76】. MIT’s OpenCourseWare content is licensed under CC BY‑NC‑SA【41876357063460†L51-L78】.

Saylor’s Operating Systems course introduces the structure and functionality of modern operating systems. It covers the fundamental abstractions used to manage concurrency and resources: processes and threads, CPU scheduling, interprocess communication, synchronisation and deadlocks. The syllabus also covers memory management techniques, file systems and storage, security mechanisms and network communication. Students learn how operating systems virtualise the CPU and memory to support multiple programs, provide isolation and protection, and enable networking and distributed applications【208816339969392†L188-L218】. Saylor Academy notes that, except for final exams and third‑party content, its course materials are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 licence【208816339969392†L350-L396】.

These slides introduce the rationale behind distributed systems. They outline three main reasons for using a distributed architecture: reliability—replicating components so that the system continues operating even if some parts fail; performance—dividing work among multiple machines to reduce latency and increase throughput; and cost—using many inexpensive computers instead of a single expensive mainframe. The slides emphasise that designing distributed systems requires understanding concurrency, partial failures and communication patterns【278074332700707†L52-L86】. The author notes that the material is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution–ShareAlike licence【278074332700707†L0-L8】.

The Cambridge concurrent and distributed systems lecture notes survey the theoretical and practical foundations of distributed computing. They describe system models that capture asynchrony, failure modes and timing assumptions; techniques for building reliable services despite partial failures; remote procedure call mechanisms; broadcast and multicast protocols; replication strategies for achieving high availability; and consensus algorithms such as Paxos and Raft. The notes also discuss eventual consistency and the trade‑offs involved when designing distributed databases. All materials are published under a Creative Commons Attribution–ShareAlike licence【827220641720192†L135-L146】.

This GitHub repository contains the LaTeX sources, slides and exercises for the University of Cambridge course on concurrent and distributed systems. The README explains that the material is available under a Creative Commons BY–SA licence and encourages readers to contribute corrections and suggestions via pull requests or issues. Resources in the repository include detailed lecture notes covering models, fault tolerance, RPC, replication and consensus, as well as problem sheets and example implementations【989950535588266†L311-L315】.

In the first lecture of George Mason University’s CS675 course, the instructor defines a distributed system as a network of computers that coordinate their actions by exchanging messages. The lecture motivates distributed systems by noting that they provide fault tolerance, scalability, cost savings and resource sharing. Examples discussed include modern data centres and frameworks like MapReduce. Characteristics of distributed systems such as concurrency, lack of a global clock and independent failures are introduced【665198267202134†L11-L33】【665198267202134†L55-L63】. The slides are licensed under a Creative Commons BY‑NC‑SA licence【665198267202134†L11-L13】.

The schedule for Princeton’s COS 418 distributed systems course outlines a sequence of lectures covering key topics. Students study time and logical clocks, remote procedure calls, eventual consistency models, consensus algorithms and fault tolerance, distributed shared memory, resource management and security. The page notes that lecture slides and related materials are provided under a Creative Commons Attribution‑NonCommercial‑ShareAlike licence【388147387657163†L11-L15】.

This OER Commons tutorial describes how to implement a distributed database system by clustering multiple database servers. It provides step‑by‑step instructions for installing and configuring the necessary open‑source software, setting up the cluster and demonstrating high availability. Learners discover how a client can connect to any server in the cluster and still access the same data, ensuring continuous service even if individual nodes fail. The resource is available under a Creative Commons Attribution‑NonCommercial licence【997226481013004†L198-L208】.

The open textbook "Semantic Web Development" introduces undergraduate students to the idea of making web content machine‑readable. It focuses on entry‑level topics such as the semantic elements of HTML5, styling with CSS3 and embedding structured data using JSON‑LD with schema.org. By following the book’s examples, readers learn how semantic markup improves searchability, data integration and interoperability on the web. Although the book mentions more advanced technologies like RDF Schema, SKOS, OWL and SPARQL, it reserves those for further study, making the text accessible to novices【97880586651737†L52-L146】. The book is distributed under a Creative Commons Attribution‑NonCommercial‑ShareAlike 4.0 licence【97880586651737†L61-L66】.

This open textbook explores how operating systems and middleware manage interactions within and between computing systems. Chapters cover threads and concurrency, CPU scheduling, synchronisation and deadlocks, atomic transactions, virtual memory, process protection, persistent storage, networking, messaging, remote procedure calls and web services, and security. Through these topics, the book explains how operating systems support controlled interaction between concurrent computations on one computer and across time and space in distributed environments. It emphasises that careful design of operating systems and middleware is essential to achieve scalability, reliability and security in modern software systems【940662000398812†L129-L172】. The work is licensed under Creative Commons Attribution–ShareAlike【940662000398812†L111-L115】.

This W3C tutorial introduces the semantic web and explains why current web pages are largely designed for human readers rather than machines. The slides discuss how adding semantic annotations to data enables tasks such as automated flight booking, data integration and improved search. By using standards like RDF and ontologies, the semantic web allows machines to understand the meaning of information, making it possible to combine data across diverse sources. The slide deck is available under a Creative Commons Attribution licence【159895969818176†L1953-L1956】.
